abstract.p: Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) are increasingly recognized as significant opportunistic pathogens in humans, yet they remain rarely implicated in cardiac conditions. Here, we report a rare case of Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection in the transverse pericardial sinus, an unusual site previously undocumented for NTM infection. The patient, a 68-year-old male with prior cardiac surgery, presented with recurrent fever lasting for over 10 days. Positron emission tomography/computed tomography demonstrated a hypermetabolic mass-like lesion within the transverse pericardial sinus, radiologically suggestive of an infectious process. Empirical broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy failed to achieve clinical response. Following surgical intervention to remove lesion tissue from the transverse pericardial sinus, histopathological analysis revealed granulomatous inflammation and acid-fast bacilli, indicating NTM infection. Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) identified MAC in the tissue sample. After starting antimycobacterial therapy, the patient's body temperature gradually returned to normal, and no recurrence was noted during a 7-month follow-up via serial surveillance imaging. This case suggests that, in patients with a history of cardiac surgery who present with unexplained pericardial or mediastinal lesions and non-diagnostic routine cultures and examinations, atypical pathogens such as NTM may warrant consideration within a broad differential diagnosis. It also illustrates the potential value of surgical intervention and mNGS in diagnosing and managing such rare infections.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) refer to mycobacterial species other than those belonging to the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and Mycobacterium leprae, which are omnipresent in the natural environment [1]. They are increasingly thought as important opportunistic pathogens of humans, with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) being the most frequently isolated species, primarily represented by Mycobacterium avium and Mycobacterium intracellulare [2], [3]. MAC can cause pulmonary and extrapulmonary disease, with the respiratory system being most common and well-known site [2]. Extrapulmonary diseases usually occur in immunosuppressed patients, commonly involving lymph nodes, skin, soft tissues, and musculoskeletal system [4]. NTM infections in cardiovascular system mostly occurred after cardiac surgery, which were mainly associated with the use of contaminated heater-cooler devices (HCDs) during cardiac surgery [5]. These cases commonly suffered endocarditis, implanted prosthetic material infection or disseminated infection caused by Mycobacterium chimaera or Mycobacterium abscessus [6], [7]. Additionally, there have been a few reported cases of MAC pericarditis in immunocompetent individuals [8]. However, MAC infection in transverse pericardial sinus has not been reported. This case highlights the importance of considering atypical pathogens as NTM in patients with transverse pericardial sinus infection, particularly when traditional diagnostic methods fail to identify the causative organism.

sec.title: Case presentation
sec.p: A 68-year-old man was admitted to our hospital for an over-10-day recurring fever (up to 38.3 °C), accompanied by chills and cough. He primarily experienced fevers in the afternoon and at night. He underwent aortic valve and ascending aortic replacement as well as pericardiectomy for aortic stenosis seven years ago. He had no history of hypertension, diabetes, immunodeficiency, or other significant medical comorbidities. He denied recent sick close contacts and travel. His vital signs on admission included a pulse rate of 95 beats/min, respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min, blood pressure of 120/76 mmHg, and temperature of 36.5°C. Auscultation found cardiac murmurs in the aortic valve area. No skin rashes were seen on inspection.

Initial laboratory evaluation showed only mild inflammatory changes, with slightly elevated C-reactive protein (26.35 mg/L; reference range, 0.00–6.00 mg/L) and procalcitonin (0.256 ng/mL; reference value, <0.05 ng/mL), and otherwise unremarkable infection markers. Sputum Gram stains, acid-fast stains and cultures, multiple blood cultures, 1–3-β-D-glucan and galactomannan (GM) were all negative. Tumor markers, an autoimmunity screening panel, and bone marrow examination revealed no significant abnormalities. Blood shotgun metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) revealed the presence of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Chest computed tomography showed scattered patchy shadows in both lungs (Fig. 1A). Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed no valvular vegetations, intracardiac masses, or pericardial effusion. Initially, empirical antimicrobial and antiviral agents, such as meropenem, doxycycline and baloxavir marboxil, were administered; however, the patient continued to experience fever. Due to the poor response to routine treatment and unclear diagnosis, the patient underwent whole-body positron emission tomography/computer tomography (PET/CT), revealing a mass mimicker in transverse pericardial sinus (adjacent to the posterior margin of the ascending aorta) with increased 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) uptake, suggestive of an infectious lesion, and patchy shadows with diffuse distribution in both lungs (Fig. 1D).Fig. 1

(D) The PET/CT revealed an increased 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose uptake adjacent to the posterior margin of the ascending aorta (arrow). Therefore, infectious disorders became the most likely diagnosis, however, deserving a microbiological diagnosis as well. At first, a minimally invasive approach was attempted by a bronchoscopy; mNGS identified EBV, pneumocystis jirovecii, gram-positive bacteria in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. Despite the antibiotic agents were switched to piperacillin/tazobactam, vancomycin, doxycycline, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ), caspofungin and baloxavir marboxil, the patient still had recurrent fever with an increase in the highest temperature, and the condition progressed to severe pneumonia (Fig. 1B, C), accompanied by type I respiratory failure and shock.

Ultimately, an open-chest surgery with excision of the lesion was performed, revealing abundant caseous material within the transverse pericardial sinus (Fig. 1G). Histology showed granulomatous inflammation with coagulative necrosis (Fig. 1H). Acid-fast staining of the surgical specimens showed acid-fast bacilli (Fig. 1I). Furthermore, surgical specimens were subjected to mNGS twice, revealing the presence of MAC and Mycobacterium avium respectively, as indicated in Table 1. As conventional culture-based molecular speciation was not available at our institution, a portion of the resected tissue was sent to a regional reference mycobacteriology laboratory for NTM culture and drug-susceptibility testing. Before these culture and susceptibility results became available, empiric antimycobacterial therapy with amikacin, azithromycin, ethambutol and rifampin had been initiated on the basis of histopathology and tissue mNGS. After prolonged incubation, culture from this specimen yielded MAC, and the treatment regimen was subsequently adjusted in accordance with the susceptibility pattern. After receiving treatment, the patient's body temperature gradually returned to normal. Two months after initiation of anti-MAC treatment, the follow-up computed tomography showed a significant improvement in bilateral pneumonia, and an obvious reduction in the size of lesions in the transverse pericardial sinus (Fig. 1E, F). No signs of recurrence were observed during the seven-month follow-up. However, anti-mycobacterial therapy was discontinued seven months later due to drug-induced liver injury, and regrettably the patient did not return for regular scheduled follow-up.Table 1

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Cardiovascular NTM infections are increasingly reported and usually manifests as endocarditis, pericarditis, or prosthetic-device infection [9], [10], [11]. This case presents a unique instance of MAC infection within the transverse pericardial sinus, an area not previously documented in the literature.

The patient presented with over ten days of recurring fever, chills, and cough, with no identifiable source of infection through traditional diagnostic methods such as sputum cultures, blood cultures, and imaging. The initial investigation suggested a viral etiology due to the detection of EBV through mNGS. However, the persistent fever and respiratory symptoms, coupled with the inconclusive results of various empirical treatments, prompted further investigation into possible infectious causes, leading to the discovery of an infectious lesion in the transverse pericardial sinus.

Notably, the PET/CT scan provided crucial insights in this case, identifying an underlying infectious site of transverse pericardial sinus. Such imaging techniques are also invaluable for guiding further invasive diagnostics. PET/CT imaging characteristics in NTM cardiovascular infections are diverse. Nearly all cases had elevated metabolic activity and 18F-FDG uptake at the infectious sites [6], [12]. Soft tissue thickening, sinus tract formation, peristernal/perigraft fluid collections and osteolysis were considered as the most common imaging features of localized infection [12]. Isolated mass-like lesions within transverse pericardial sinus as in this case are rare.

The utilization of mNGS also proved pivotal in this case, enabling the identification of atypical pathogens that traditional methods failed to reveal. The diagnosis of MAC infection was confirmed through histological examination and mNGS of surgical specimens, underscoring the importance of advanced diagnostic techniques in cases with atypical presentations.

This case underscores the potential risk of NTM infections in patients who have undergone cardiac surgery, particularly those who have been exposed to contaminated HCDs, known reservoirs for Mycobacterium chimaera and Mycobacterium abscessus [5], [6]. While these species are often associated with endocarditis and prosthetic infections, the identification of MAC in this case suggests that it may also pose a risk for localized infections in areas such as the transverse pericardial sinus.

After surgical intervention and identification of MAC as the causative agent, the patient was placed on a targeted antimycobacterial therapy regimen. The initiation of treatment led to a significant clinical improvement, reflected in the normalization of body temperature and the reduction of lesions in subsequent imaging studies. This outcome reinforces the necessity of prompt and accurate identification of NTM infections to facilitate timely and appropriate therapy. Meanwhile, surgical intervention should be considered in patients with localized lesion.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, this case illustrates that NTM can present with a localized infection of the transverse pericardial sinus after cardiac surgery and may manifest primarily with non-specific systemic symptoms. In such situations, comprehensive diagnostic strategies that combine advanced imaging, histopathology, and, where feasible, surgical sampling with mNGS test can be valuable for establishing an etiologic diagnosis and guiding targeted antimicrobial therapy. Given increasing prevalence of NTM in post-surgical settings, maintaining high clinical suspicion is essential. Further studies are warranted to better understand the risk factors, clinical manifestations, and optimal management strategies for this population.
